descendants.content:
My favorite bird on our Greenland trip is the fulmar, an albatross-like pelagic bird that races just above the ocean, one wingtip almost touching the water. They're graceful, efficient fliers and, more impressively, were unbothered by near-freezing rain and gale-force wind.

#Birds #NaturePhotography #Birding #Greenland #Photography #TravelPhotography

descendants.content: An arctic fox on an island near Qeqertarsuatsiaat, Greenland. This one was with a cub we saw carrying a big fish in its mouth. It watched us very intently. I love the thick fur (the cub was even poofier) and the rounded ears, both adapted for withstanding cold. #WildlifePhotography #Greenland #Fox #NaturePhotography #Photography #TravelPhotography

media_attachments.description: A chocolate-brown arctic fox with a very thick tail and rounded ears looks toward the photographer with yellow eyes. The fox is standing amid low grass and shrubs with a few white flowers nearby.

descendants.content:
Humanity is a thin layer atop the Greenlandic rock, with almost no soil to bury water pipes or electrical conduit. Greenland blends subsistence hunting Inuit culture with Danish colonial culture; the latter contributed the colorful house style. This is Qaqortoq, population 3,000 (5% of Greenland's total population of about 56,000).

#TravelPhotography #Greenland #Architecture #Photography

media_attachments.description: A collection of houses and other buildings, each painted a single solid color, perched on Greenland's hard rocky ground.

descendants.content:
I photographed these icebergs near Ilulissat, Greenland, 23 minutes before midnight, awhile before sunset. I went to bed at 9 p.m. but randomly woke up at 11:20 p.m. or so, peeked out the window, and grabbed my camera. The distant one I call the Castle was enormous.

Next day a huge storm set in. Gray, cold, dark, huge waves — totally different. #Greenland #TravelPhotography #Iceberg #ClimateChange #Photography #NaturePhotography #Arctic

media_attachments.description: A collection of Arctic icebergs near and far on a calm sea, including one shaped like a giant castle on the horizon. The water and sky are lit pale yellow by sunset light.

descendants.content:
Greenland weather is unpredictable — several planned excursions were canceled because of storms or icepack — but that once gave us time to check a random fjord where there were a pair of bearded seals, or as I would call them, mustached seals. Tubular!

#WildlifePhotography #Photography #NaturePhotography #Greenland #TravelPhotography #MarineMammal #Fjord

media_attachments.description: A very plump bearded seal, with up-curling whiskers and forepaws that look like very thick mittens, raises its head as it rests on an ice floe.

descendants.content:
At first we thought this iceberg looked like a gingerbread house. As we got closer, I decided it was more like a sphinx with paws outstretched. Beautiful midnight vistas on an all-but-freezing, calm sea north of the Arctic Circle just before the storm hit.

#Greenland #NaturePhotography #ClimateChange #Iceberg #Sunset #Ice

descendants.content:
Greenland can't join FIFA because the football (aka soccer) organization requires natural turf that just won't grow. Greenlanders use artificial turf. Imagine playing on this field in Qaquertarsuak north of the Arctic Circle, with icebergs floating in the ocean just beyond the goal.

#Football #Soccer #Greenland #TravelPhotography #Iceberg

descendants.content: @redrummy They're both worthwhile. Like Alaskan Inside Passage, Greenland is optimized for ship cruises. This time we did Iceland in a rental camper van (kind of beat up but workable), which was a good combination of affordable (compared to hotels/Airbnb) and mobile.

account.note:
He/Him. Retired Oracle DBA, Toad MVP, developer, husband, geek, not a dad, open source contributor. McLaren & Mercedes F1 fan.

I own a Huawei P20 phone with the Leica camera. I try to take at least 1 half decent photo every day if I can.

In 2020, Apress published my 1st book, 'Arduino Software Internals'. My 2nd, 'Arduino Interrupts', was published in 2023. I'm now writing a 3rd plus a 2nd edition of 'Internals'.

Currently living in Yorkshire, UK.

No longer on Twitter as @NormanDunbar.

fields.name: Books I've written.

Arduino Software Internals - April 2020.
Arduino Interrupts - December 2023.
Arduino Software Internals, Second Edition - coming later in 2024.

descendants.content:
@stshank Canada made it to the World Cup in '86 by beating Honduras because they played them on a field in Newfoundland where the temperature was only 11 degrees!

That's probably another reason that Greenland doesn't have a team. I think environment conditions, like altitude in the Andes, limits where games can be played now.

https://www.cbc.ca/archives/why-the-weather-mattered-when-canada-tried-reaching-the-world-cup-in-1985-1.6237105

account.note:
IT contractor in #Ottawa, Canada
#dotnet #csharp #fullstack

#QueensU engineering alumnus, former #infantry soldier, rides #motorcycles, hispanohablante (más o menos).

I'm here to improve my snark game. My views should be yours too.

Blocked by NotJustBikes for asserting that bicycles are vehicles and therefore they belong on the roads.

card.description: Chilly temperatures and rainy skies seemed to be on their side when the Canadian men's soccer team was preparing for a crucial match in St. John's in 1985.

descendants.content: @rjohnston Greenland only has a population of 56,000 and even with fake grass, it's hard to find that much flat space without a lot of dynamite. Greenland villages/towns tend to be draped across a very forbidding, rocky landscape. The capital, Nuuk, has a population of ~18,000, same as my (small) home town in New Mexico.
